newsitem.title: USA: Fed's Rivlin - wage growth not boosting inflation.
newsitem.headline: Fed's Rivlin - wage growth not boosting inflation.

text.p: Recent growth in U.S. wages has not sparked inflation yet because productivity appears to be growing even faster, Alice Rivlin, vice-chairwoman of the Federal Reserve said Friday.

"There is no strong evidence that the wage growth is proceeding faster than the productivity increase at the moment," Rivlin told reporters after moderating a panel at a Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta Conference here.
"Eventually, if wage increases are not matched by productivity increases, they will lead to inflation," Rivlin said. "But that's not happening yet."

Rivlin observed that the current U.S. economic conditions have put the Fed on alert for signs of inflation. "The risks are on the upside when you have tight labor markets for a very long time -- you should be vigilant," Rivlin said, adding the Fed is being vigilant currently.
"The economy's on a good track at the moment," she said.
Asked if the strong dollar was helping to curb inflation, Rivlin said, "It certainly helps, it's an off-setting factor."
Rivlin explained that a strong dollar could hurt U.S. exporters but noted that "American industry is much more competitive than it used to be."
Asked about the risk of inflation accelerating in coming months, Rivlin said the current unusual economic conditions made it difficult to predict.

"I very frankly think we don't know," Rivlin said. "This is a situation that we really haven't been in before: Very tight labor markets for a long time with relatively moderate wage increases and very little if any inflation.
"How long can this go on?" Rivlin asked. "We don't really know. We aren't even sure why it's happening exactly."

Although the Federal Reserve has not paid close attention to monetary aggregates in recent years, Rivlin said M2 may now be "behaving in a more regular way," thus making it more "interesting" to the Fed in the future.
